thread.title: Football: Fort Smith Southside rolls over Rogers Heritage
thread.title_full: Football: Fort Smith Southside rolls over Rogers Heritage

title: Football: Fort Smith Southside rolls over Rogers Heritage
text:
By Paul Boyd Posted: October 17, 2015 at 1 a.m. 
ROGERS --Fort Smith Southside rang up a pair of early scores and then rode its defense to a 20-0 win over Rogers Heritage in 7A-West Conference action Friday night at Gates Stadium. 
Senior quarterback Cooper Johnson scored two first-half touchdowns and ran for 100 yards as the Rebels jumped to a 20-0 halftime lead and cruised to the victory. 
7A-West Conference 
Fort Smith Southside 20, Rogers Heritage 0 
Fort Smith Southside^13^7^0^0^—^20 
Rogers Heritage^0^0^0^0^—^0 
First Quarter 
South-Rogers 10 run (kick failed), 6:39. 
South-Johnson 2 run (Guiterrez kick), :00. 
Second Quarter 
South-Johnson 1 run (Guiterrez kick), 2:17. 
Southside coach Jeff Williams acknowledged the second half in particular wasn't a thing of beauty, but praised his defense for the shutout. Johnson threw an interception on Southside's first play from scrimmage, but the Southside defense responded. 
The Rebels (4-3, 2-2 7A-West) blocked a Heritage field goal attempt to finish its initial drive, then responded by going 65 yards in nine plays, leaning heavily on the runing game. 
Junior Kobe Rogers finished the drive with a 10-yard touchdown run, but the PAT was wide, leaving the score 6-0 with 6 minutes, 39 seconds left in the opening quarter. 
"It was pretty ugly, especially in the second half, but you'll take a win in this league any time you can get it," Williams said. "Our defense played really well. Just real sloppy in the second half. But blocking the field goal and getting some momentum going early was big." 
"We had some mishaps and first cold night we've had. The ball seems a little harder sometimes. The offense just didn't get in a great rhythm, especially in the second half. But I thought in the first half we played pretty good." 
After Southside forced a Heritage punt, the Rebels again put together a 76-yard scoring drive with just one pass completion. Johnson finished it with a 2-yard sneak as the opening quarter ended. The PAT was good this time and Southside pushed its lead to 13-0. 
The Rebels added another score just before halftime. The 67-yard drive was keyed by a 42-yard gain on a swing pass from Johnson to junior Parker Dixon. Johnson finished off the drive with a 1-yard plunge on third-and-goal. 
Heritage coach Perry Escalante against praised the work of his defense, but acknowledged losing three starters to injuries was problematic. Linebacker Jovanni Gonzalez, receiver/running back Dylan Qualls and defensive lineman Andy Mendoza all left the game and did not return. 
"They played hard, hard hard," Escalante said. "We got two picks and a fumble recovery. They are just so beat up. We're just physically beat up. It doesn't get any easier. We're going in with a beat up and battered team. We've just got to go back to work." 
Heritage's best drive of the night came following the interception by senior David Zamora near midfield in the first quarter. The War Eagles (0-7, 0-4) drove to the Southside 15, but Aaron Pavlak's 36-yard field goal attempt was blocked. 
Heritage did not get inside the Southside 30 the rest of the night.
